Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I accept, but I insist on a wager. The loser must do whatever the winner pleases.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Agreed.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Do you see the gate at the end of the field?  The first to touch it will be the winner.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Your penalty is to find a cherry- colored ribbon which I have hidden somewhere on my person.  You are free to look for it anywhere you will, and I will think very little of you if you do not find it.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I feel the ribbon.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Then you must get it.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Why are you shaking?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: With pleasure at finding the ribbon.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Sure it's a bitter night, Roderick dear, and you'll catch cold without a handkerchief to your neck.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Did you and Miss Clancy have a pleasant evening, Roderick?  You were together, I saw, all night.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Oh!  Mercy, you make Daisy rear and throw me, you careless creature, you.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I hate Miss Clancy, you know I do! And I only danced with her because -- because -- the person with whom I intended to dance chose to be engaged the whole night.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: I had not been in the room five minutes before I was engaged for every single set.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Were you obliged to dance five times with Captain Best, and then stroll out with him into the garden?

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: I don't care a fig for Captain Best; he dances prettily to be sure, and is a pleasant rattle of a man.  He looks well in his regimentals, too; and if he chose to ask me to dance, how could I refuse him?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: But you refused me, Dorothy.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Oh!  I can dance with you any day, and to dance with your own cousin at a ball as if you could find no other partner.  Besides, Roderick, Captain Best's a man, and you are only a boy, and you haven't a guinea in the world.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: If ever I meet him again, you shall see which is the best man of the two.  I'll fight him with sword or with pistol, captain as he is.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: But Captain Best is already known as a valiant soldier, and is famous as a man of fashion in London.  It is mighty well of you to fight farmers' boys, but to fight an Englishman is a very different matter.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Suppose, now, Roderick, you, who are such a hero, was passing over the bridge and the enemy on the other side.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I'd draw my sword, and cut my way through them.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: What, with me on the pillion?  Would you kill poor me?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Well, then, I'll tell you what I'd do.  I'd jump Daisy into the river, and swim you both across, where no enemy could follow us.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Jump twenty feet!  You wouldn't dare to do any such thing on Daisy. There's the captain's horse, Black George, I've heard say that Captain Bes --

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Hold tight to my waist!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Whose horse, fellow, is that?

Speaker: orderly
Dialogue: Feller, indeed!  The horse belongs to my captain, and he's a better fellow nor you any day.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: No, Dorothy, except for you and four others, I vow before all the gods, my heart had never felt the soft flame.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Ah, you men, you men, John, your passion is not equal to ours.  We are like -- like some plant I've read of -- we bear but one flower, and then we die!

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: Do you mean you never felt an inclination for another?

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Never, my John, but for thee!  How can you ask me such a question?

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: Darling Dorothea!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: She's a liar -- she's a liar, Captain Best!  Draw, sir, and defend yourself, if you are a man!

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Captain Best, for Heaven's sake, spare the child -- he is but an infant.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: And ought to be whipped for his impudence, but never fear, Miss Dugan, I shall not touch him, your favorite is safe from me.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: When ladies make presents to gentlemen, it is time for other gentlemen to retire...

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Good heavens, Best!  He is but a boy and don't signify any more than my parrot or lap-dog.  Mayn't I give a bit of ribbon to my own cousin?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I'm a man, and will prove it.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: You are perfectly welcome, miss, as many yards as you like.

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Monster!  Your father was a tailor, and you are always thinking of the shop.  But I'll have my revenge, I will!  Roddy, will you see me insulted?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Indeed, Miss Dorothy, I intend to have his blood as sure as my name's Roderick.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: I'll send for the usher to cane you, little boy, but as for you, miss, I have the honor to wish you a good day.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Hoity-toity!  John Best, what's the matter here?

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: I'll tell you what it is, Mr. Dugan. I have had enough of Miss Dugan here and your Irish ways.  I ain't used to 'em, sir.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Well, well!  What is it?  We'll make you used to our ways, or adopt English ones.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: It's not the English way, for ladies to have two lovers, and, so, Mr. Dugan, I'll thank you to pay me the sum you owe me, and I resign all claims to this young lady.  If she has a fancy for school-boys, let her take 'em, sir.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Pooh!  Pooh!  Best, you are joking.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: I never was more in earnest.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You -- you!  Hang you for a meddling brat, your hand is in everybody's pie.  What business had you to come brawling and quarreling here, with a gentleman who has fifteen hundred a-year?

Speaker: dorothy
Dialogue: Oh, I shall die; I know I shall.  I shall never leave this spot.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: The Captain is gone.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: This is a pretty way to recommend yourself to the family.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: The man that marries Dorothy Dugan must first kill me -- do you mind that?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Pooh, sir.  Kill you -- flog you, you mean!  I'll send for Nick the huntsman to do it.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: You are a gallant lad, and I like your spirit.  But what Dugan says is true.  It's a hard thing to give a lad counsel who is in such a far- gone state as you; but, believe me, I know the world, and if you will but follow my advice, you won't regret having taken it.  Dorothy Dugan has not a penny; you are not a whit richer.  And, my poor boy, don't you see -- though it's a hard matter to see -- that she's a flirt, and does not care a pin for you or Best either?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Dorothy might love me or not, as she likes, but Best will have to fight me before he marries her!

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: Faith, I think you are a lad that's likely to keep your word.

Speaker: maid
Dialogue: The Englishman's still there, Master Roderick.  He's there in the parlor. Go in, and don't let 'im browbeat you, Master Roderick.

Speaker: uncle
Dialogue: Hello, Roddy, my boy!  Up and well? That's right.

Speaker: aunt
Dialogue: He'd better be home with his mother.

Speaker: uncle
Dialogue: Don't mind her.  It's the cold goose she ate for breakfast -- didn't agree with her.  Take a glass of spirits, Mrs. Dugan, to Roderick's health.

Speaker: uncle
Dialogue: Dorothy, divide that merry thought with the captain!  See who'll be married first.  Jack Best, my dear boy, never mind a clean glass for the claret, we're short of crystal at Castle Dugan; take Dorothy's and the wine will taste none the worse. Mrs. Dugan and ladies, if you please; this is a sort of toast that is drunk a great deal too seldom in my family, and you'll please to receive it with all the honors. Here's to Captain and Mrs. John Best, and long life to them.  Kiss her, Jack, you rogue; for faith, you've got a treasure.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: His already?!

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Hold your tongue, you fool -- hold your tongue!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: He has already been slapped in the face this morning, Captain John Best; he's already been called a coward, Captain John Best; and this is the way I'll drink his health. Here's your health, Captain John Best.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You fool!  You great blundering marplot -- you silly beggarly brat --  Hold your tongue!

Speaker: uncle
Dialogue: In Heaven's name, what does all the row mean?  Is the boy in fever again?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: The fact is, sir, that the young monkey has fallen in love with Dorothy, and finding her and the captain mighty sweet in the garden today, he was for murdering Jack Best.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: And, I'll tell you what, Mr. Dugan, I've been insulted grossly in this house.  I ain't at all satisfied with these here ways of going on. I'm an Englishman, I am, and a man of property; and I -- I --

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: If you're insulted, and not satisfied, remember there's two of us, Best.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Mr. Best may also have satisfaction any time he pleases, by calling on Roderick James, Esquire, of Jamesville.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Captain Grogan, I beg you to understand that, for my cousin Harry, who has been my best friend through life, I could put up with rough treatment from him; yet, even that sort of treatment I will bear from him no longer; and any other person who ventures on the like will not like the cost.  Mr. Best knows that fact very well; and, if he's man, he'll know where to find me.

Speaker: uncle
Dialogue: It is getting late, and your mother will be anxious about you.  One of you had better go home with him.  Or the lad may be playing more pranks.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Both of us ride home with Best here.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: I'm not afraid of highwaymen.  My man is armed, and so am I.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You know the use of arms very well, Best, and no one can doubt your courage; but Michael and I will see you home for all that.

Speaker: uncle
Dialogue: Why, you'll not be home till morning, boys.  Kilwangan's a good ten miles from here.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: We'll sleep in Best's quarters. We're going to stop a week there. And, in another week, my boy.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: I'll go home with the boy.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: A pretty day's work of it you have made, Master Roderick.  Knowing your uncle to be distressed for money, and try and break off a match which will bring fifteen hundred a-year into the family?  Best has promised to pay off the four thousand pounds which is bothering your uncle so. He takes a girl without a penny -- a girl that has been flinging herself at the head of every man in these parts these ten years past, and missing them all, and a boy who ought to be attached to your uncle as to your father.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: And so I am.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: And this is the return you make for his kindness!  Didn't he harbor you in his house when your father died, and hasn't he given you and your mother, rent-free, your fine house of Jamesville yonder?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Mark this, come what will of it, I swear I will fight the man who pretends to the hand of Dorothy Dugan.  I'll follow him if it's into the church, and meet him there. I'll have his blood, or he shall have mine.  Will you take my message to him, and arrange the meeting?

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: Well, if it must be, it must.  For a young fellow, you are the most bloodthirsty I ever saw.  No officer, bearing His Majesty's commission, can receive a glass of wine on his nose, without resenting it -- fight you must, and Best is a huge, strong fellow.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: He'll give the better mark.  I am not afraid of him.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: In faith, I believe you are not; for a lad I never saw more game in my life.  Give me a kiss, my dear boy. You're after my own soul.  As long as Jack Grogan lives, you shall never want a friend or a second.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Thank God, it's fallen towards me!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Have you taken my message to him?

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: The meeting is arranged.  Captain Best is waiting for you now.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: My mare is saddled and ready; who's the captain's second?

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: Your cousins go out with him.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: That's a very handsome sword you have there.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: It was with this sword that my late father, Harry James, God rest his soul, met Sir Huddelstone Fuddelstone, the Hampshire baronet, and was fatally run through the neck.  He was quite in the wrong, having insulted Lady Fuddelstone, when in liquor, at the Brentford Assembly.  But, like a gentleman, he scorned to apologize.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: And now you risk the same fate.  If you are killed, your mother is all alone in the world.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I am Harry James' son, and will act as becomes my name and quality.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I hope to spoil this sport, and trust to see this sword of mine in that big bully's body.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: Oh, it's with pistols we fight.  You are no match for Best with the sword.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I'll match any man with the sword.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: But swords are today impossible; Captain Best is -- is lame.  He knocked his knee against the swinging park gate last night, as he was riding home, and can scarce move it now.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Not against Castle Dugan gate, that has been off the hinges these ten years.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: It must have been some other gate.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: I have just explained to Mister James that Captain Best is lame, and that swords are impossible.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Oh, yes!  Dead lame.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: And very lucky for you, Roderick, my boy.  You were a dead man else, for he is a devil of a fellow -- isn't he, Grogan?

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: A regular Turk.  I never yet knew the man who stood to Captain Best.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Hang the business.  I hate it.  I'm ashamed of it.  Say you're sorry, Roderick.  You can easily say that.

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: If the young feller will go to Dublin, as proposed...

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I'm not sorry -- I'll not apologize -- and I'll as soon go to Dublin as to hell!

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: Look here, Roderick, my boy; this is silly business.  The girl will marry Best, mark my words; and as sure as she does, you'll forget her.  You are but a boy.  Best is willing to consider you as such.  Dublin's a fine place, and if you have a mind to take a ride thither and see the town for a month, here are twenty guineas at your service.  Make Best an apology, and be off.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: A man of honor dies, but never apologizes.  I'll see the captain hanged before I apologize.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: There's nothing else for it.  Take your ground, Grogan -- twelve paces, I suppose?

Speaker: captain best
Dialogue: Ten, sir, and make them short ones, do you hear, Captain Grogan?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Don't bully, Mr. Best.  Here are the pistols.  God bless you, my boy; and when I count three, fire.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: This is not one of my pistols.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: They are all right, never fear. It's one of mine.  Yours will serve, if they are needed, for the next round.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: Roderick, fire at his neck -- hit him there under the gorget; see how the fool shows himself open.

Speaker: the seconds
Dialogue: He's down!  He's down!

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: He's hit here, in the neck.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: How is it with you?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The young fellow has begun well. You had better ride off, young sir, before the police are up.  They had wind of the business before we left Kilwangan.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Is he quite dead?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Quite dead.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: Then the world's rid of a coward. It's all over with him, Roddy -- he doesn't stir.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: We are not cowards, Grogan, whatever he was!  Let's get the boy off as quick as we may.  Your man shall go for a cart, and take away the body of this unhappy gentleman.  This has been a sad day's work for our family, Roderick James, and you have robbed us of fifteen-hundred a-year.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: It was Dorothy did it.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: There!  Take her those ribbons. She'll know what they mean; that's all that's left of her of two lovers she had and ruined.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: And now, in Heaven's name, get the youngster out of the way.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I'll go with you.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: The boy must go into hiding, for a short time anyway.  Dublin is the best place for him to go, and there wait until matters are blown over.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Dublin?  But the poor lad has never been away from home.  He will be as safe here as in Dublin.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I wish that were true, Auntie dear, but I'm afraid the bailiffs may already be on their way from Kilwangan.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Roderick, my darling, my wild boy, I have forebodings that our separation is to be a long one.  I spent most of all night consulting the cards regarding your fate in the duel, and all signs betoke a separation.  Here is twenty guineas -- all that I have in the world -- and I want you to keep your father's sword and pistols, which you have known to use so like a man.

Speaker: armed gentleman
Dialogue: Good day to you, young sir.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: armed gentleman
Dialogue: Where are you bound for?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: That is none of your business.

Speaker: armed gentleman
Dialogue: Is your mother not afraid on account of the highwayman to let one so young as you travel?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Not at all, sir.  I have a pair of good pistols that have already done execution, and are ready to do it again.

Speaker: footman
Dialogue: Stop thief!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: What is this noise, fellows?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: What has happened, madam, to annoy your ladyship?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Have you lost much?

Speaker: footman
Dialogue: Be fair, ma'am, them wasn't so much. Didn't he return you the thirteen pence in copper, and the watch, saying it was only pinchbeck?

Speaker: footman
Dialogue: Sorry, ma'am.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I am riding to Dublin myself, and if your ladyship will allow me the honor of riding with you, I shall do my best to protect you from further mishap.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: O'Higgins... Mohawk O'Higgins.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: As you have been robbed of your purse, may I have permission to lend your ladyship a couple of pieces to pay any expenses which you might incur before reaching your home?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I am only sorry that I was unable to prevent the villain from carrying off all her ladyship's money and pearls.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Which O'Higgins do you know?  For I have never heard your name mentioned in my family.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Ah -- I see.  No, I'm afraid mine are the O'Higgins of Watertown.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I shall have to write out a note for the rest of it, Captain O'Reilly.

Speaker: councillor mulligan
Dialogue: Master Roderick, you appear a young fellow of birth and fortune; let me whisper in your ear that you have fallen into very bad hands -- it's a regular gang of swindlers; and a gentleman of your rank and quality should never be seen in such company.  The captain has been a gentleman's gentleman, and his lady of no higher rank.  Go home, pack your valise, pay the little trifle you owe me, mount your mare, and ride back again to your parents -- it's the very best thing you can do.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Sirrah!  Sirrah, I am as good a gentleman as any in Ireland!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Repeat the words again, and I run you through the body.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Hark ye, Mr. O'Reilly, I will tell you why I was obliged to alter my name, which is James and the best name in Ireland.  I changed it, sir, because, on the day before I came to Dublin, I killed a man in deadly combat -- an Englishman, sir, and a Captain in His Majesty's service; and if you offer to let or hinder me in the slightest way, the same arm which destroyed him is ready to punish you.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I will tell you frankly, sir.  I am a young gentleman in difficulties; I have killed an officer in a duel, and I am anxious to get out of the country.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Fellow, get me a glass!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Is it a towel of your wife's washing, Mr. Toole?  I'm told she wiped your face often with one.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: I had news of you in Dublin.  Faith, you've begun early, like your father's son, but I think you could not do better than as you have done. But why did you not write home to your poor mother?  She has sent half-a-dozen letters to you in Dublin.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I suppose she addressed them to me in my real name, by which I never thought to ask for them at the post office.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: We must write to her today, and you can tell her that you are safe and married to "Brown Bess."

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: I see you are thinking of a certain young lady at Duganstown.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Is Miss Dugan well?

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: There's only six Miss Dugans now... poor Dorothy.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Good heavens!  Whatever?  Has she died of grief?

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: She took on so at your going away that she was obliged to console herself with a husband.  She is now Mrs. John Best.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Mrs. John Best!  Was there another Mr. John Best?!

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: No, the very same one, my boy.  He recovered from his wound.  The ball you hit him with was not likely to hurt him.  It was only made of tow. Do you think the Dugans would let you kill fifteen hundred a-year out of the family?  The plan of the duel was all arranged in order to get you out of the way, for the cowardly Englishman could never be brought to marry from fear of you.  But hit him you certainly did, Roderick, and with a fine thick plugget of tow, and the fellow was so frightened that he was an hour in coming to. We told your mother the story afterwards, and a pretty scene she made.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: The coward!

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: He has paid off your uncle's mortgage.  He gave Dorothy a coach- and-six.  That coward of a fellow has been making of your uncle's family.  Faith, the business was well done.  Your cousins, Michael and Harry, never let him out of their sight, though he was for deserting to England, until the marriage was completed, and the happy couple off on their road to Dublin.  Are you in want of cash, my boy?  You may draw upon me, for I got a couple of hundred out of Master Best for my share and, while they last, you shall never want.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Grogan's down; Lakenham, there's your company.

Speaker: captain grogan
Dialogue: I should have left you a hundred guineas, Roderick, but for a cursed run of ill-luck last night at faro.

Speaker: lakenham
Dialogue: Here, you, Roderick James.  I will pay you five guineas if you will carry me into the town which is hard by those woods.

Speaker: private
Dialogue: I should get half.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Your share is one guinea.

Speaker: private
Dialogue: He gave you five guineas, and I bloody well expect half.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Go to the devil.

Speaker: lakenham
Dialogue: Who are you putting into that bed?

Speaker: lischen
Dialogue: We have the Corporal, wounded, to you bringing.

Speaker: lakenham
Dialogue: A corporal?  Turn him out.  Schicken sie Herrn Koporal weg!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I'm promoted Lieutenant.  I've come to take my leave of you.  I intend to have your papers and purse.

Speaker: lakenham
Dialogue: You great scoundrel!  You mutinous dog!  What do you mean by dressing yourself in my regimentals?  As sure as my name's Lakenham, when we get back to the regiment, I'll have your soul cut out of your body.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Hark ye, sir!  No more noise, or you are a dead man!

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: What is your uncle's name?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: O'Grady.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Oh, yes, of course, Ambassador O'Grady...

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: It hurts my feelings to be obliged to commune with such wretches, but the stern necessities of war demand men continually, and hence these recruiters whom you see market in human flesh.  They get five-and- twenty thaler a man from our government for every man they bring in.  For fine men -- for men like you.  They would go as high as hundred.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: This is a very good inn.  Shall we stop for dinner?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: This may be a very good inn for Germany, but it would not pass in old Ireland.  Corbach is only a league off, let us push on for Corbach.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Do you want to see the loveliest woman in Europe?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Ah!  You sly rogue, I see that will influence you.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: The place seems more a farm than an inn-yard.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: The people are great farmers, as well as inn-keepers.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Parties of French horsemen are about the country, and one cannot take too many precautions against such villains.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Well, our meal is a frugal one, but a soldier has many a time a worse.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Where's the beauty you promised me?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: It was my joke.  I was tired, and did not care to go farther.  There's not prettier woman here than that. If she won't suit your fancy, my friend, then you must wait awhile.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Upon my word, sir, I think you have acted very coolly.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: I have acted as I think fit.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Sir, I'm a British officer.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: It's a lie!  You're a deserter! You're an impostor, sir; Your lies and folly have confirmed this to me. You pretend to carry dispatches to a general who has been dead these ten months; you have an uncle who is an ambassador and whose name you don't know.  Will you join and take the bounty, sir, or will you be given up?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Neither!

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Advance a step, and I send this bullet into your brains!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I volunteer.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I had formed myself to the condition of the proper fighting beast; on a day of action, I was savage and happy.

Speaker: colonel bulow
Dialogue: You are a gallant soldier, and have evidently come of good stock; but you are idle, dissolute, and unprincipled; you have done a deal of harm to the men; and, for all your talents and bravery, I am sure you will come to no good.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I hope Colonel Bulow is mistaken regarding my character.  I have fallen into bad company, it is true; but I have only done as other soldiers have done; and, above all, I have never had a kind friend and protector before, to whom I might show that I was worthy of better things.  The Colonel may say I am a ruined lad, and send me to the devil; but be sure of this, I would go to the devil to serve the regiment.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Private Roderick James.  First Hanoverian Guards.  Captain Galgenstein sent for me.

Speaker: prussian sergeant
Dialogue: You may wait.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: private
Dialogue: Sergeant, the wagon has arrived with the Captain's furniture, but the driver says he is not supposed to unload it.  Is it possible for you to talk to him?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Good morning, Private James.  Please come in.  I should like you to meet my uncle, Herr Minister of Police Galgenstein.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: How do you do, sir?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Your loyalty to me and your service to the regiment has pleased me very well -- and now there is another occasion on which you may make yourself useful to us; if you succeed, depend on it, your reward will be your discharge from the army, and a bounty of 100 guineas.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: What is the service, sir?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: There is lately come to Berlin a gentleman in the service of the Empress Queen, who calls himself the Chevalier de Belle Fast, and wears the red riband and star of the pope's order of the Spur.  He is made for good society, polished, obliging, a libertine, without prejudices, fond of women, of good food, of high play, prudent and discreet.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: He speaks Italian and French indifferently; but we have some reason to fancy this Monsieur de Belle Fast is a native of your country of Ireland, and that he has come here as a spy.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Naturally, your knowledge of English makes you an ideal choice to go into his service.  Of course, you will not know a word of English; and if the Chevalier asks as to the particularity of your accent, say you are Hungarian.  The servant who came with him will be turned away today, and the person to whom he has applied for a faithful fellow will recommend you.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: You are a Hungarian; you served in the army, and left on account of weakness in the loins.  He gambles a great deal, and wins.  Do you know the cards well?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Only a very little, as soldiers do.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: I had thought you more expert.  You must find out if the Chevalier cheats.  He sees the English and Austrian envoys continually, and the young men of either ministry sup repeatedly at his house.  Find out what they talk of, for how much each plays, especially if any of them play on parole.  If you are able to, read his private letters, though about those which go to the post, you need not trouble yourself -- we look at them there.  But never see him write a note without finding out to whom it goes, and by what channel or messenger.  He sleeps with the keys of his dispatch-box with a string around his neck -- twenty frederics, if you get an impression of the keys.

Speaker: minister galgenstein
Dialogue: Does this assignment interest you?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes, Minister, I am interested in any work in which I can be of service to Captain Galgenstein.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: You are the young man who M. de Seebach recommended?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes, sir.  Here is my letter.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Your name is Lazlo Zilagyi?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: You come highly recommended by Herr Seebach.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Herr Seebach was a very kind employer.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: For whom else have you worked?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: No one, sir.  Before that I served in the army but had to leave due to weakness of the loins.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Who else can give me information about you?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Only the agency of servants.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: You will do.  I will give you 30... a day.  I do not provide your clothing; you will sleep at home, and you will be at my orders every morning at seven o'clock.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Is there something wrong?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Sir, I have a confession to make.  I am an Irishman, and my name is Roderick James.  I was abducted into the Prussian army two years ago, and now I have been put into your service by my Captain and his uncle, the Minister of Police, to serve as a watch upon your actions, of which I am to give information to the same quarter.  For this odious service, I have been promised my discharge, and a hundred guineas.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: The rascals!  They think to catch me, do they?  Why, young man, my chief conspiracy is a faro-bank. But the king is so jealous, that he will see a spy in every person who comes to his miserable capital, in the great sandy desert here.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: I'd give five years of my life to see the old country again, the greenfields, and the river, and the old round tower, and the burying place.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: My lad, I have been in every service; and, between ourselves, owe money in every capital in Europe.  I have been a rolling stone.  Play -- play has been my ruin!  That and beauty.  The women have made a fool of me, my dear boy.  I am a soft- hearted creature, and this minute, at sixty-two, have no more command of myself than when Peggy O'Dwyer made a fool of me at sixteen.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: The cards are now my only livelihood.  Sometimes I am in luck, and then I lay out my money in these trinkets you see.  It's property, look you, and the only way I have found of keeping a little about me. When the luck goes against me, why, my dear, my diamonds go to the pawnbrokers and I wear paste.  Do you understand the cards?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I can play as soldiers do, but have no great skill.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: We will practice in the mornings, my boy, and I'll put you up to a thing or two worth knowing.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: He goes to church regularly -- he is very religious, and after hearing mass comes home to breakfast.  Then he takes an airing in his chariot till dinner, which is served at noon.  After dinner, he writes his letters, if he has any letters to write; but he has very little to do in this way.  His letters are to the Austrian envoy, with whom he corresponds, but who does not acknowledge him; and being written in English, or course, I look over his shoulder.  He generally writes for money.  He makes his party with Calsabigi, the lottery contractor, the Russian attaches, two from the English embassy, my lords Deuceace and Punter, who play a jeu d'enfer, and a few more.  He wins often, but not always.  Lord Deuceace is a very fine player.  The Chevalier Elliott, the English Minister, sometimes comes, on which occasion the secretaries do not play.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Chevalier, though I cannot say how, I believe you have cheated me.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: I deny your Grace's accusations, and beg you to say how you have been cheated?

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Your Grace owes me seventy thousand frederics, which I have honorably won.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: Chevalier, if you will have your money now, you must fight for it. If you will be patient, maybe I will pay you something another time.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Your Grace, if I am so tame as to take this, then I must give up an honorable and lucrative occupation.

Speaker: prince
Dialogue: I have said all there is to be said. I am at your disposal for whatever purposes you wish.  Good night.

Speaker: minister galgenstein
Dialogue: Was he cheated?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: In so far as I can tell these things -- no.  I believe the Chevalier won the money fairly.

Speaker: minister galgenstein
Dialogue: Hmm-mmmm.

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: What are the Chevalier's intentions?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I am not sure.  The Prince told him quite clearly that if he wished to have the money, he would have to fight for it.

Speaker: minister galgenstein
Dialogue: A meeting with the Prince of Turbingen is impossible.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: The Prince left him only that choice.

Speaker: minister galgenstein
Dialogue: Will you be able to return here tomorrow without arousing suspicion?

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Tell them I intend to demand satisfaction from the Prince.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: But they will prevent a meeting at whatever the cost.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Have no fear.  It will come out well for me.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I believe they will deport you.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: I have faced that problem before.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: But, if they send you away, then what is to become of me?

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Make your mind easy, you shall not be left behind, I warrant you.  Do take a last look at your barracks, make your mind easy, say a farewell to your friends in Berlin.  The dear souls, how they will weep when they hear you are out of the country, and, out of it, you shall go.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: But how, sir?

Speaker: minister galgenstein
Dialogue: The King has determined to send the Chevalier out of the country.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: When is he to go?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Has he sent the challenge yet?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Not yet, but I believe he intends to.

Speaker: minister galgenstein
Dialogue: Then this must be done tomorrow.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: What is to be done?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: You say he drives after breakfast and before dinner.  When he comes out to his carriage a couple of gendarmes will mount the box, and the coachman will get his orders to move on.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: And his baggage?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Oh!  That will be sent after him.  I have a fancy to look into that red box which contains his papers, you say; and at noon, after parade, shall be at the inn.  You will not say a word to any one there regarding the affair, and will wait for me at the Chevalier's rooms until my arrival.  We must force that box.  You are a clumsy hound, or you would have got the key long ago.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Where is my rascal, Lazlo?

Speaker: prussian officer
Dialogue: I will let down the steps for your honor.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Good gracious!  What is this?

Speaker: prussian officer
Dialogue: You are going to drive to the frontier.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: It is shameful -- infamous!  I insist upon being put down at the Austrian ambassador's house.

Speaker: prussian officer
Dialogue: I have orders to gag your honor if you cry out, and to give you this purse containing ten thousand frederics if you do not.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Ten thousand?  But the scoundrel owes me seventy thousand.

Speaker: prussian officer
Dialogue: Your honor must lower his voice.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: All Europe shall hear of this!

Speaker: prussian officer
Dialogue: As you please.

Speaker: prussian officer
Dialogue: Do not be alarmed.  The alarm cannon only signals a deserter.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: I have no luggage.

Speaker: prussian officer
Dialogue: The gentleman has nothing contraband.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I wish you a good day. Will you please go to the house from whence we set out this morning, and tell my man there to send my baggage on to Three Kings at Dresden?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: Roderick!  Are you there?

Speaker: captain galgenstein
Dialogue: The rogue is gone out.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Where is my servant?  Who dares to rob me in open day?  Look at the villain whom I find in the act of breaking my chest open!  Send for the police, send for his Excellency the Austrian Minister!  All Europe shall know of this insult!

Speaker: landlord
Dialogue: Dear heaven!  We saw you go away three hours ago.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Me!  Why, man, I have been in bed all morning.  I am ill -- I have taken physic -- I have not left the house this morning!  Where is that scoundrel, Lazlo?  But, stop!  Where are my clothes and wig?

Speaker: chambermaid
Dialogue: I have it -- I have it!  Lazlo is off in your honor's dress.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: And my money -- my money!  Where is my purse with forty-eight frederics in it?  But we have one of the villains left, Officers, seize him.

Speaker: landlord
Dialogue: It's the young Herr Galgenstein.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: What!  A gentleman breaking open my trunk with hammer and chisel -- impossible!

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Sir, we have but eighty thousand florins in bank, or two hundred thousand at three months; if your highness' bags do not contain more than eight thousand, we will meet you.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Do you expect me to believe that your lover brought you here tonight?

Speaker: valdez
Dialogue: Yes.  He brought me in his carriage, and he will call for me at midnight.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: And he doesn't care about me?

Speaker: valdez
Dialogue: He is only curious to know who you are.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: If his love were like mine, he would not permit you to come here.

Speaker: valdez
Dialogue: He loves me, as I love you.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Will he wish to know the details of this night?

Speaker: valdez
Dialogue: He will believe that it will please me if he asks about it, and I shall tell him everything except some circumstances which might humiliate him.

Speaker: langeac
Dialogue: I will put in on you myself.

Speaker: langeac
Dialogue: There you are, dressed by my hand. It is nearly the same thing; but despite the fineness and transparency of the skin, the little fellow pleases me less well in costume.  It seems that this covering degrades him, or degrades me -- one of the other.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Both, my angel.  It was Love who invented these little jackets:  for he had to ally himself with Precaution.

Speaker: count
Dialogue: I entered here, monsieur, at a bad moment for you; it seems that you love this lady.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Certainly, monseigneur, does not Your Excellency consider her worthy of love?

Speaker: count
Dialogue: Perfectly so; and what is more, I will tell you that I love her, and that I am not of a humor to put up with rivals.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Very well!  Now that I know it, I will no longer love her.

Speaker: count
Dialogue: Then you yield to me.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: On the instant.  Everyone must yield to such a nobleman as you.

Speaker: count
Dialogue: Very well; but a man who yields takes to his legs.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: That is a trifle strong.

Speaker: count
Dialogue: Take to your legs, low Irish dog.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Your Excellency has wantonly insulted me.  That being so, I conclude that you hate me, Monseigneur, and that hence you would be glad to remove me from the number of the living.  In this wish, I can and will satisfy Your Excellency.

Speaker: dascher
Dialogue: I see that you are without your sword, but I believe you are a man of mettle.  Will you give me satisfaction?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I shall be delighted; but you have lost and you must pay me the money before we meet, for, after all, you cannot pay me when you are dead.

Speaker: another officer
Dialogue: I will undertake to pay you the 20 louis, but only tomorrow morning at the meeting.

Speaker: dascher
Dialogue: I may have been mistaken, but I mean to make you pay deadly for your brutality.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: It is distasteful to kill a scoundrel -- that should be work for a hangman.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: To risk one's life against such people is an imposition.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I risk nothing, for I am certain to kill him.

Speaker: chevalier
Dialogue: Certain?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Perfectly certain, because I shall make him tremble.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: You have only to pace yourself at ten paces difference, and fire first.  The space between these two trees is the place where I choose to walk back and forth.  You may walk too, if you wish, when it is my turn to fire.

Speaker: dascher
Dialogue: But we must decide who is to have the first shot.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: There is no need of that.  I never fire first; and, in any case, you have that right.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: You missed me, sir.  I was sure you would.  Try again.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I am posting, monsieur, and furthermore I am a foreigner.

Speaker: stranger
Dialogue: Monsieur, here in Saxony, the post has no special right, and if you are a foreigner, you must admit that you have no greater claim than mine, since I am in my own country.

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Hang it, Mr. Roderick James, you have no more manners than a barber, and I think my black footman has been better educated than you; but you are a young fellow of originality and pluck, and I like you, sir.  because you seem determined to go to the devil by a way of your own.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I am obliged to observe, Sir William Cosgrove, that since you are bound for the next world much sooner than I am, I will depend on you to get comfortable quarters arranged for me.

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Indeed, you are right, sir.  Look at me.  Marriage has added forty years to my life.  I am dying, a worn-out cripple, at the age of fifty.  When I took off Lady Cosgrove, there was no man of my years who looked so young as myself.  Fool that I was! I had enough with my pensions, perfect freedom, the best society in Europe -- and I gave up all these, and married and was miserable.  Take a warning from me, Mr. Roderick, and stick to the trumps.  Do anything, but marry.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Would you have me spend my life all alone?

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: In truth, sir, yes, but, if you must marry, then marry a virtuous drudge.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: The milkmaid's daughter?

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Well, why not a milkmaid's daughter? No man of sense need restrict himself or deny himself a single amusement for his wife's sake; on the contrary, if he selects the animal properly, he will choose such a one as shall be no bar to his pleasure, but a comfort in his hours of annoyance.  For instance, I have got the gout; who tends me?  A hired valet who robs me whenever he has the power.  My wife never comes near me.  What friend have I?  None in the wide world.  Men of the world, as you and I are, don't make friends, and we are fools for our pains.

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: My lady is a weak woman, but she is my mistress.  She is a fool, but she has got the better of one of the best heads in Christendom.  She is enormously rich, but somehow I have never been so poor, as since I married her.  I thought to better myself, and she has made me miserable and killed me, and she will do as much for my successor when I'm gone.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Has her ladyship a very large income?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Charming lady, tell me the truth and earn my gratitude.  Have you a lover?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Have you had one?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Never.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: But, for a time... a passing fancy?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Not even that.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: How can I believe that there is not a man who has inspired desires in you?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Not one.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Have you not a man whom you value?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: That man has, perhaps, not yet been born.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: What!  You have not met a man worthy of your attention?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Many worthy of attention; but valuing is something more.  I could value only someone whom I loved.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Then you have never loved?  Your heart is empty.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Your word "empty" makes me laugh. Is it fortunate, or unfortunate?  If it is fortunate, I congratulate myself.  If it is unfortunate, I do not care, for I am not aware of it.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: It is nonetheless a misfortune, and you will know it when you love.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: But if, when I love, I am unhappy, I will know that my empty heart was my good fortune.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: That is true, but it seems to me impossible that you should be unhappy in love.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: It is only too possible.  Love requires a mutual harmony which is difficult, and it is even more difficult to make it last.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I agree; but God put us on earth to take that risk.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: A man may need to do that, and find it amusing; but a girl is bound by other laws.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I believe you, and I see I must hasten to leave, for otherwise I shall become the unhappiest of men.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: By loving you, with no hope of possessing you.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: You want my heart?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: It is my only object.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: To make me wretched in two weeks.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: To love you until death.  To subscribe to all your commands.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: The amusing thing is that you deceive me without knowing, if it is true that you love me.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Deceiving someone without knowing it is something new for me.  If I do not know it, I am innocent.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: But you deceive me nonetheless if I believe you, for it will not be in your power to love me when you love me no longer.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Be so good as to tell me with whom you think you are?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: With a woman who is completely charming, be she a princess or a woman of the lowest condition, and who, regardless of her rank, will show me some kindness, tonight.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: And if she does not choose to show you some kindness?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Then I will respectfully take leave of her.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: You will do as you please.  It seems to me that such a matter can hardly be discussed until after people know each other.  Do you not agree?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes -- but I am afraid of being deceived.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Poor man.  And, for that reason, you want to begin where people end?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I ask only a payment on account today -- after that, you will find me undemanding, obedient and discreet.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Will we always leave it at this?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Always, my dear one, never any further.  Love is a child to be pacified with trifles.  A full diet can only kill it.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I know better than you do.  Love wants a more substantial fare, and if it is stubbornly withheld, it withers away.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Our abstinence makes our love immortal.  If I loved you a quarter of an hour ago, now I should love you even more.  But I should love you less if you exhausted my joy by satisfying all my desires.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Let us give each other complete happiness, and let us be sure that as many times as we satisfy our desires, they will each time be born anew.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: My husband has convinced me of the contrary.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Sir William Cosgrove is a man who is dying, and yet I envy him more than any man in Christendom.  He enjoys a privilege of which I am deprived. He may take you in his arms whenever he pleases, and no veil keeps his senses, his eyes, his soul from enjoying your beauty.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Shall I tell you something -- I believed what was called love came after the union -- and I was surprised when my husband, making me a woman, made me know it only by pain, unaccompanied by any pleasure. I saw that my imaginings had stood me in better stead.  And so we became only friends, seldom sleeping together and arousing no curiosity in each other, yet on good terms for a while, as whenever he wanted me, I was at his service, but since the offering was not seasoned with love, he found it tasteless, and seldom demanded it.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: O, my dearest love.  Enough!  I beg you.  Stop believing in your experience.  You have never known love.  My very soul is leaving me! Catch it on your lips, and give me yours!

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Without you, my dearest, I might have died without ever knowing love. Inexpressible love!  God of nature! Bitterness than which nothing is sweeter, sweetness than which nothing is more bitter.  Divine monster which can only be defined by paradoxes.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Let me give a thousand kisses to that heavenly mouth which has told me that I am happy.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: As soon as I saw you loved me, I was pleased, and I gave you every opportunity to fall more in love with me, being certain that, for my part, I would never love you.  But after our first kiss, I found that I had no power over myself.  I did not know that one kiss could matter so much.

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Good evening, Mr. James, have you done with my lady?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I beg your pardon?

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Come, come, sir.  I am a man who would rather be known as a cuckold than a fool.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I think, Sir William Cosgrove, you have had too much drink.  Your chaplin, Mr. Hunt, has introduced me into the company of your lady to advise me on a religious matter, of which she is a considerable expert.

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Gentlemen, see this amiable youth! He has been troubled by religious scruples, and has flown for refuge to my chaplin, Mr. Hunt, who has asked for advise from my wife, Lady Cosgrove, and between them both, they are confirming my ingenious young friend in his faith.  Did you ever hear of such doctors and such a disciple?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Faith, sir, if I want to learn good principles, it's surely better I should apply for them to your lady, and your chaplin than to you?

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: He wants to step into my shoes!  He wants to step into my shoes!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Well, if my intentions are what you think they are -- if I do wish to step into your shoes, what then?  I have no other intentions than you had yourself.  Lady Cosgrove's wealth may be great, but am I not of a generous nature enough to use it worthily?  Her rank is lofty, but not so lofty as my ambition.  I will be sworn to muster just as much regard for my Lady Cosgrove as you ever showed her; and if I win her, and wear her when you are dead and gone, corbleu, knight, do you think that it will be the fear of your ghost will deter me?

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one; my wife so fond of me, that she is even now thinking of appointing a successor?  Isn't it a comfort to see her; like a prudent housewife, getting everything ready for her husband's departure?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, knight?

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps.  Why, man, I have been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.  Who knows how long I may keep you waiting.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Sir, let those laugh that win.

Speaker: sir william
Dialogue: I am sorry for you Mr. James.  I'm grieved to keep you or any gentleman waiting.  Had you not better to arrange with my doctor or get the cook to flavor my omelette with arsenic?  What are the odds, gentlemen, that I don't live to see Mr. James hang yet?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Dies at Spa, in the Kingdom of Belgium, the Right Honorable Sir William Cosgrove, Knight of the Bath, Member of Parliament for Cosgrove and Devonshire and many years His Majesty's representative at various European courts.  He hath left behind him a name which is endeared to all his friends for his manifold virtues and talents, a reputation justly acquired in the service of His Majesty, and an inconsolable widow to deplore his loss.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: My Lord Brookside, come and embrace your papa!

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: He, my father!  I would as soon call one of your ladyship's footmen, papa!

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Lord Brookside, you have offended your father.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: Mother, you have offended my father.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: Dear child, what a pity it is I am not dead for your sake!  The Cosgroves would then have a worthy representative, and enjoy all the benefits of the illustrious blood of the James' of Duganstown, would they not, Mr. James Cosgrove?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Ah, Roderick, it's a blessing to see that my darling boy has attained a position I always knew was his due, and for which I pinched myself to educate him.  Little Patrick is a darling boy, and you live in great splendor, but how long will it last? Your lady-wife knows she has a treasure she couldn't have had, had she taken a duke to marry her, but if, one day, she should tire of my wild Roderick and his old-fashioned Irish ways, or if she should die, what future would there be for my son and grandson?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You have not a penny of your own, and cannot transact any business without the Countess' signature. Upon her death, the entire estate would go to young Brookside, who bears you little affection.  You could be penniless tomorrow, and darling Patrick at the mercy of his stepbrother.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I shall tell you a secret -- I shall not rest until I see you Earl of Duganstown, and my grandson, a Lord Viscount.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: This head would become a coronet.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: These things entail considerable expense, and you will need your lady's blessing, but the young boy forms the great bond of union between you and her ladyship, and there is no plan of ambition you could propose in which she would not join for the poor lad's benefit, and no expense she will not eagerly incur, if it might be any means be shown to tend to his advancement. You have important friends, and they can tell you how these things are done.

Speaker: lord west
Dialogue: Do you happen to know Gustavus Adolphus, the thirteenth Earl of Crabs?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: By name only.

Speaker: lord west
Dialogue: Well, sir, this nobleman is one of the gentlemen of His Majesty's closet, and one with whom our revered monarch is on terms of considerable intimacy.  I should say you would be wise to fix upon this nobleman your chief reliance for the advancement of your claim to the Viscounty which you propose to get.

Speaker: george iii
Dialogue: That's right, Mr. Cosgrove, raise another company, and go with them, too!

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: If I were you, Mr. Cosgrove, I should mind my horses and tailors and not trouble myself about letters.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Dr. Johnson, I think you misbehave most grossly, treating my opinions with no more respect than those of a schoolboy.  You fancy, sir, you know a great deal more than me, because you quote your "Aristotle" and "Plato," but can you tell me which horse will win at Epsom Downs next week?  Can you shoot the ace of spades ten times without missing? If so, talk about Aristotle and Plato with me.

Speaker: boswell
Dialogue: Do you know who you're speaking to?!

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: Hold your tongue, Mr. Boswell, I had no right to brag of my Greek, gentlemen, and he has answered me very well.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Do you know ever a rhyme for Aristotle?

Speaker: goldsmith
Dialogue: Port, if you please.

Speaker: johnson
Dialogue: Waiter, bring on of Captain James' rhymes for Aristotle.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I am at your service, Mr. Cosgrove. How much do you wish to spend?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: As much as possible.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: As much as possible?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes, for I wish to entertain splendidly.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: All the same, you must name an amount.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: It is entirely up to you.  I want the best.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Will that be enough?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Last month, the Duke of Suffolk spent no more.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: All right, five hundred guineas.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Papa, please don't flog Brookside today.  It wasn't his fault -- really is wasn't.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: Look you now, Mister Roderick James, from this moment on, I will submit to no further chastisement from you! Do you understand that?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Give me that pistol.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: Take heed, Mister James.  I will shoot you if you lay hands on me now, or ever again.  Is that entirely clear to you, sir?

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: Don't you think he fits my shoes very well, Sir Richard Wargrave?

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: From the manner in which I love this child, my lord, you ought to know how I would have loved his elder brother, had he proved worthy of any mother's affection.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: Madam, I have borne as long as mortal could endure the ill- treatment of the insolent Irish upstart, whom you have taken into your bed.  It is not only the lowness of his birth, and the general brutality of his manners which disgusts me, but the shameful nature of his conduct towards your ladyship, his brutal and ungentlemanlike behavior, his open infidelity, his habits of extravagance, intoxication, his shameless robberies and swindling of my property and yours.  It is these insults to you which shock and annoy me more than the ruffian's infamous conduct to myself.  I would have stood by your ladyship, as I promised, but you seem to have taken latterly your husband's part; and, as I cannot personally chastise this low-bred ruffian, who, to our shame be it spoken, is the husband of my mother, and as I cannot bear to witness his treatment of you, and loathe his horrible society as if it were the plague, I am determined to quit my native country, at least during his detested life, or during my own.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Sire, my Lord Brookside has set sail to fight the rebels against Your Majesty's crown in America.  Does Your Majesty desire that I should send another company to aid him?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Thus it is that my loyalty is rewarded, and my sacrifices in favor of my country viewed!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I insist upon being allowed to appear before His Majesty and clear myself of the imputations against me, to point out my services to the government, and to ask when the reward, that had been promised me, the title held by my ancestors, is again to be revived in my person.

Speaker: lord west
Dialogue: Have you done, Mr. Cosgrove?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: lord west
Dialogue: Well, Mr. Cosgrove, I'll answer you point by point.  The King is exceedingly averse to make peers, as you know.  Your claim, as you call them, have been laid before him, and His Majesty's gracious reply was, that you were the most impudent man in his dominions, and merited a halter, rather than a coronet.  As for withdrawing your support from us, you are perfectly welcome to carry yourself whithersoever you please.  And, now, as I have a great deal of occupation, perhaps you will do me the favor to retire, or tell me if there is anything else in the world in which I can oblige you.

Speaker: broker
Dialogue: Your wife's life is as well known among the insurance societies in London, as any woman in Christendom, and, I'm sorry to say there is not one of them willing to place another policy against her ladyship's life. One of them even had the impudence to suggest that your treatment of the Countess did not render her life worth a year's purchase.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Timmy, take the injured lad to see the doctor, and then bring the horse to Doolan's farm, and tell him to break him in thoroughly.  Tell him it's for little Patrick, and that I'll be over to see him next week.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: One more thing, and listen well, I don't want little Patrick to know where the horse is being kept.  It's going to be surprise for his birthday.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Hello, papa!

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Did you buy the horse, papa?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Now, just have a little patience, my boy.  Your birthday isn't until next week.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: But I will have it on my birthday, won't I?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Well, we'll just have to wait and see, won't we?

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Good night, papa.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Good night, my little darling.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Papa?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: One of the boys in the stable told Nelly that you've already bought my horse, and that it's at Doolan's farm, where Mick the groom is breaking it in.  Is that true, papa?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: What the devil?  What kind of fools do we have here?  Pottle, who told the lad this story?

Speaker: hunt
Dialogue: I don't know, sir.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Then it's true!  It's true!  Oh, thank you, papa!  Thank you!

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Promise me, Patrick, that you will not ride the horse except in the company of your father.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: I promise, mama.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I promise your lordship a good flogging if you even so much as go to Doolan's farm to see him.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Yes, papa.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes...?

Speaker: valet
Dialogue: I'm sorry to disturb you, sir, but Mr. Hunt has something important to tell you.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: hunt
Dialogue: I think Master Patrick has disobeyed your orders and stolen off to Doolan's farm.  When I went to the lad's room this morning, his bed was empty.  One of the cooks said she saw him go away before daybreak.  He must have slipped through my room while I was asleep.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: You won't whip me, will you, papa?

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Papa, I beg you and mama to pardon me for any acts of disobedience I have been guilty of towards you.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Oh, my little angel, you have done nothing for which you need pardon.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Where is Brooksy?  I would like to see him.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Your bother is in America fighting the rebels.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Is he all right, papa?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes, he's fine.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: Brooksy was better than you, papa, he used not to swear so, and he taught me many good things while you were away.

Speaker: patrick
Dialogue: I beg you not to quarrel so, but to love each other, so that we might meet again in heaven where Brooksy told me quarrelsome people never go.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: "This day, three years ago, my last hope and pleasure in life was taken from me, and my dear child was called to Heaven.  Where is his neglected brother, whom I suffered to grow up unheeded by my side, and whom the tyranny of the monster to whom I am united drove to exile, and, perhaps to death?  I pray the child is still alive and safe. Charles Brookside!  Come to the aide of a wretched mother, who acknowledges her crime, her coldness towards you, and now bitterly pays for her error!  What sufferings, what humiliations have I had to endure!  I am a prisoner in my own halls.  I should fear poison, but then I know the wretch has a sordid interest in keeping me alive, and that my death would be the signal for his ruin.  But I dare not stir without my odious, hideous, vulgar gaoler, the horrid Irish woman, who purses my every step.  I am locked into my chamber at night, like a felon, and only suffered to leave it when ordered into the presence of my lord, to be present at his orgies with his boon-companions, and to hear his odious converse as he lapses into the disgusting madness of intoxication."

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Roderick, you know well enough that I have never loved but you!  Was I ever so wretched that a kind word from you did not make me happy? Ever so angry, but the least offer of good-will on your part did not bring me to your side?  Did I not give a sufficient proof of my affection for you in bestowing one of the finest fortunes of England upon you?  Have I repined or rebuked you for the way you have wasted it? No, I loved you too much and too fondly; I have always loved you. From the first moment I saw you, I saw your bad qualities, and trembled at your violence; but I could not help loving you.  I married you, though I knew I was sealing my own fate in doing so, and in spite of reason and duty.  What sacrifice do you want from me?  I am ready to make any, so you will but love me, or, if not, that at least, you will gently us me.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Depend on it, artful hussy has some other scheme in her head now.

Speaker: newcombe
Dialogue: I have good news for you, Mr. Cosgrove.  The firm of Bracegirdle and Chatwick, in the city of London, are prepared to lend you 20,000 pounds, pledged against your interest in the Edric mines.  They will redeem the encumbrances against the property, which amount to some 10,000 pounds, and take a twenty- year working lease on the mines. They will lend you the 20,000 pounds against the lease income, which they will apply to the loan as it comes in, and they will make a charge of 18% per annum interest on the outstanding loan balance.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Mr. Newcombe, I have made some difficult loans during the past few years, at very onerous terms, but 18% a year interest seems very stiff indeed.

Speaker: newcombe
Dialogue: Considering your financial circumstances, Mr. Cosgrove, it has been impossible to find anyone at all prepared to do any business with you.  I think you may count yourself lucky to have this opportunity. But, obviously, if you would reject this offer, I shall keep trying to find a better one.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I am prepared to accept the terms, Mr. Newcombe.

Speaker: newcombe
Dialogue: There are a few other points we should discuss.  The loan agreement can only be executed by her ladyship's signature, and provided that Bracegirdle and Chatwick can be assured of her ladyship's freewill in giving her signature.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Provided that they can be assured of her ladyship's freewill?  Are you serious?

Speaker: newcombe
Dialogue: May I be quite frank with you?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Yes, of course.

Speaker: newcombe
Dialogue: Mister Bracegirdle said to me that he had heard her ladyship lives in some fear of her life, and meditated a separation, in which case, she might later repudiate any documents signed by herself while in durance, and subject them, at any rate, to a doubtful and expensive litigation. They were quite insistent on this point, and said they must have absolute assurance of her ladyship's perfect freewill in the transaction before they would advance a shilling of their capital.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: newcombe
Dialogue: When I asked them in what form they would accept her ladyship's assurances, they said that they were only prepared to accept them if her ladyship confirms her written consent by word of mouth, in their presence, at their counting-house in Birchin Lane, London.  I requested they come here, and save her ladyship and yourself the inconvenience of the trip to London, but they declined, saying that they did not wish to incur the risk of a visit to Castle Hackton to negotiate, as they were aware of how other respectable parties, such as Messrs. Sharp and Salomon had been treated here.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Depend on it, there is some artifice.  When once you get into that wicked town, you are not safe. There are scores of writs out against you for debt.  If you are taken in London, and thrown into prison, your case is hopeless.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Mother dear, we are now living off our own beef and mutton.  We have to watch Lady Cosgrove within and the bailiffs without.  There are certain situations in which people cannot dictate their own terms; and faith, we are so pressed now for money, that I would sign a bond with old Nick himself, if he would provide a good round sum.  With this money, we can settle our principal debts and make a fresh start.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Roderick, you must listen to me.  As soon as they have you in London, they will get the better of my poor innocent lad; and the first thing that I shall hear of you will be that you are in trouble.  You will be a victim of your own generous and confiding nature.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Why go, Roderick?  I am happy here, as long as you are kind to me, as you now are.  We can't appear in London as we ought; the little money you will get will be spent, like all the rest has been.  Let us stay here and be content.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Humph!  I believe she is at the bottom of it -- the wicked schemer.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Roderick -- don't go in.  I am sure there is danger.  There's time yet, let us go back -- anywhere!

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Lady Cosgrove, you are an old fool.

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Old fool!

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Say Lady Cosgrove is here!

Speaker: countess
Dialogue: Oh fool as I am, I have outwitted the most crafty and treacherous monster under the sun.  Yes, I was a fool when I married you, and gave up other and nobler hearts for your sake -- yes, I was a fool when I forgot my name and lineage to unite myself with a base-born adventurer -- a fool to bear, without repining, the most monstrous tyranny that ever woman suffered; to allow my property to be squandered; to see women as base and low-born as yourself...

Speaker: tapewell
Dialogue: For heaven's sake, be calm.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: You didn't tell all, my lady -- I said "old" fool.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: I have no doubt that you said and did, sir, everything that a blackguard could say or do.  This lady is now safe under the protection of her relations and the law, and need fear your infamous persecutions no longer.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: But you are not safe, and as sure as I am a man of honor, I will have your heart's blood.

Speaker: tapewell
Dialogue: Take down his words, constables; swear the peace against him.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: I would not sully my sword with the blood of such a ruffian.  If the scoundrel remains in London another day, he will be seized as a common swindler.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Where's the man who will seize me?

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Let the scoundrel come!  You -- you cowardly braggart, come first, if you have the soul of a man!

Speaker: tapewell
Dialogue: We are not going to seize you!  My dear sir, we don't wish to seize you; we will give you a handsome sum to leave the country, only leave her ladyship in peace.

Speaker: brookside
Dialogue: And the country will be rid of such a villain.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Gentlemen, I shall have no violence; you may tell Mr. Tapewell I am quite ready to speak with him when he is at leisure.

Speaker: tapewell
Dialogue: I have been authorized by Lady Cosgrove and her advisors to pay you an annuity of 300 pounds a year, specifically on the condition of you remaining abroad out of the three kingdoms, and to be stopped on the instant of your return.  I advise you to accept it without delay for you know, as well as I do, that your stay in London will infallibly plunge you in gaol, as there are innumerable writs taken out against you here and in the west of England, and that your credit is so blown upon that you could not hope to raise a shilling.  I will leave you the night to consider this proposal, but if you refuse, the family will proceed against you in London, and have you arrested.  If you accede, a quarter salary will be paid to you at any foreign port you should prefer.

Speaker: roderick
Dialogue: Mr. Tapewell, I do not require a night to consider this proposal. What other choice has a poor, lonely and broken-hearted man?  I shall take the annuity, and leave the country.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: Mr. James Cosgrove's personal narrative finishes here, for the hand of death interrupted the ingenious author soon after the period which this memoir was compiled, after he had lived nineteen years an inmate of the Fleet Prison, where the prison records state he died of delirium tremens.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: His faithful old mother joined him in his lonely exile, and had a bedroom in Fleet Market over the way.  She would come and stay the whole day with him in prison working.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: The Countess was never out of love with her husband, and, as long as she lived, James enjoyed his income of 300 pounds per year and was, perhaps, as happy in prison, as at any period of his existence.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: When her ladyship died, her son sternly cut off the annuity, devoting the sum to charities, which, he said, would make a nobler use of it than the scoundrel who had enjoyed it hitherto.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: When the famous character lost his income, his spirit entirely failed. He was removed into the pauper's ward, where he was known to black boots for wealthier prisoners, and where he was detected in stealing a tobacco box.

Speaker: narrator
Dialogue: His mother attained a prodigious old age, and the inhabitants of the place in her time can record, with accuracy, the daily disputes which used to take place between mother and son, until the latter, from habits of intoxication, falling into a state of almost imbecility, was tended by his tough old parent as a baby almost, and would cry if deprived of his necessary glass of brandy.
